The '''largest known prime number''' ({{as of|2018|November|lc=y}}) is 277,232,917 − 1, a number with 23,249,425 digits. It was found by the [[Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search]] (GIMPS) in 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.mersenne.org/primes/press/M77232917.html|title=50th Known Mersenne Prime Discovered|website=www.mersenne.org|access-date=2018-01-04}} [[File:Digits in largest prime 2016.svg|thumb|400px|Plot of the number of digits in largest known prime by year, since the electronic computer. The vertical scale is [[logarithmic scale|logarithmic]]. The red line is the exponential curve of [[Curve fitting|best fit]]: ''y'' = exp(0.187394 ''t'' - 360.527), where ''t'' is in years.]] [[Euclid]] [[Euclid's theorem|proved that]] there is no largest [[prime number]], and many mathematicians and hobbyists continue to search for large prime numbers. Many of the largest known primes are [[Mersenne prime]]s. {{As of|2018|July}}, the seven largest known primes are Mersenne primes.{{cite web |url=https://primes.utm.edu/primes/search.php?Number=100 |title=The largest known primes - Database Search Output |first1=Chris |last1=Caldwell |date= |publisher=Prime Pages |access-date=June 3, 2018}} The last sixteen record primes were Mersenne primes.{{cite web |url=http://primes.utm.edu/notes/by_year.html |title=The Largest Known Prime by Year: A Brief History |first1=Chris |last1=Caldwell |date= |publisher=Prime Pages |access-date=January 20, 2016}}The last non-Mersenne to be the largest known prime, was [http://primes.utm.edu/primes/page.php?id=390 391,581 ⋅ 2216,193 − 1]; see also [http://primes.utm.edu/notes/by_year.html The Largest Known Prime by Year: A Brief History] by Caldwell. The [[fast Fourier transform]] implementation of the [[Lucas–Lehmer primality test]] for [[Mersenne number]]s is fast compared to other known primality tests for other kinds of numbers. ==Current record== The record is currently held by 277,232,917 − 1 with 23,249,425 digits, found by [[Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search|GIMPS]] in December 2017. Its value is: {{quote|4673331833592310999883355855611155212513211028177144957985823385935679234805211772074843110997402088496251368090038049317 ... (23,249,185 digits omitted) ... 285376004518786055402223376672925679282131965467343395945397370476369279894627999939614659217371136582730618069762179071|sign=|source=|style=word-wrap: break-word}} The first and last 120 digits are shown above. ==Prizes== The [[Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search]] (GIMPS) currently offers a US$3000 research discovery award for participants who download and run their free software and whose computer discovers a new Mersenne prime having fewer than 100 million digits. There are several prizes offered by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] for record primes. GIMPS is also coordinating its long-range search efforts for primes of 100 million digits and larger and will split the Electronic Frontier Foundation's US$150,000 prize with a winning participant. The record passed one million digits in 1999, earning a US$50,000 prize.Electronic Frontier Foundation, [https://www.eff.org/press/releases/big-prime-nets-big-prize Big Prime Nets Big Prize]. In 2008 the record passed ten million digits, earning a US$100,000 prize and a [[Cooperative Computing Award]] from the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]].{{cite web |url=https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2009/10/14-0 |title=Record 12-Million-Digit Prime Number Nets $100,000 Prize |date=October 14, 2009 |work=Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |accessdate=November 26, 2011 }} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' called it the 29th-top invention of 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1852747_1854195_1854157,00.html |title=Best Inventions of 2008 - 29. The 46th Mersenne Prime |work=Time |publisher=[[Time Inc]] |accessdate=January 17, 2012 |date=October 29, 2008}} Both the US$50,000 and the US$100,000 prizes were won by participation in GIMPS. Additional prizes are being offered for the first prime number found with at least one hundred million digits and the first with at least one billion digits. ==History== The following table lists the progression of the largest known prime number in ascending order. "Wing-In-Ground effect vehicles") are classified as maritime ships, rather than aircraft, by the International Maritime Organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.imo.org/OurWork/Safety/Regulations/Pages/WIG.aspx|title=Wing-in-Ground (WIG) craft|author=Sub-Committee on Ship Design and Equipment (DE) |date=November 2001|publisher=International Maritime Organization|accessdate=16 January 2014}} {{clear}} ==Spacecraft== {{main|List of spaceflight records#Speed and altitude}} [[File:ApolloX CommandModule London.jpg|thumb|[[Apollo 10]] [[Apollo Command/Service Module|command module]] ''Charlie Brown'', the fastest manned vehicle relative to the Earth]] In order to unambiguously express the speed of a spacecraft, a [[frame of reference]] must be specified. Typically, this frame will be fixed to the body with the largest [[Sphere of influence (astrodynamics)|gravitational influence]] on the spacecraft, as this is the most relevant frame for most purposes.{{cite news|last1=McKinnon|first1=Mika|title=Was Juno the fastest spacecraft ever? Only kind of.|url=http://www.astronomy.com/news/2016/07/juno-may-not-have-been-the-fastest-spacecraft-ever|accessdate=12 July 2016|work=Astronomy|date=12 July 2016}} Velocities in different frames of reference are not directly comparable; thus the matter of the "fastest spacecraft" depends on the reference frame. Because of the influence of gravity, maximum velocities are usually attained just after launch, at entry, or at time of [[periapsis|closest approach]] to a massive body. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; width: 75%" |- ! '''Lustre''' is the [[codename]] of a [[secret treaty]] signed by [[France]] and the [[UKUSA Agreement|Five Eyes]] (FVEY) for cooperation in [[signals intelligence]] and for mutual data exchange between their respective [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]]. Its existence was revealed during the 2013 [[global surveillance disclosure]] based on documents leaked by the former NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name="lemonde1" /><ref name="leparis">{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/espionnage-la-france-aurait-collabore-avec-la-nsa-29-10-2013-3268865.php |title=Espionnage : la France aurait collaboré avec la NSA |author=Le Parisien |work=Le Parisien |language=French |date=2013-10-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGz9tnV6?url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/espionnage-la-france-aurait-collabore-avec-la-nsa-29-10-2013-3268865.php |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="numera">{{cite web|url=http://www.numerama.com/magazine/27347-lustre-la-france-aurait-coopere-avec-la-nsa.html |title=Lustre : la France aurait coopéré avec la NSA |author=Guillaume Champeau |work=Numerama |language=French |date=2013-10-28 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGzKojEl?url=http://www.numerama.com/magazine/27347-lustre-la-france-aurait-coopere-avec-la-nsa.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="zdnet">{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.fr/actualites/espionnage-la-france-perd-son-lustre-39795120.htm |title=Espionnage : la France perd son Lustre |author=ZDNet.fr |work=ZDNet - France |language=French |date=2013-10-28 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGzbCyjF?url=http://www.zdnet.fr/actualites/espionnage-la-france-perd-son-lustre-39795120.htm |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{global surveillance}}
== Historical background ==
The [[Directorate-General for External Security]] (DGSE) of France maintains a close relationship with both the NSA and the GCHQ after discussions for increased cooperation began in November 2006.<ref name=frlemjac>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/technologies/article/2013/11/29/la-france-precieux-partenaire-de-l-espionnage-de-la-nsa_3522653_651865.html |title=La France, précieux partenaire de l'espionnage de la NSA |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2013-11-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2013-11-30 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20131130144856/http://www.lemonde.fr/technologies/article/2013/11/29/la-france-precieux-partenaire-de-l-espionnage-de-la-nsa_3522653_651865.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> By the early 2010s, the extent of cooperation in the joint interception of digital data by the DGSE and the NSA was noted to have increased dramatically.<ref name=frlemjac /><ref name="rfi-dgse-nsa-partnerschaft">{{cite web |url=http://www.rfi.fr/ameriques/20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine/?ns_campaign=google_choix_redactions&ns_fee=0&ns_linkname=ameriques.20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine&ns_mchannel=editors_picks&ns_source=google_actualite |title=Espionnage: les services secrets français précieux partenaires de la NSA américaine |author=Radio France Internationale |work=Radio France Internationale |language=French |date=2013-11-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH01RbbB?url=http://www.rfi.fr/ameriques/20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine/?ns_campaign=google_choix_redactions&ns_fee=0&ns_linkname=ameriques.20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2011, a formal [[memorandum]] for data exchange was signed by the DGSE and the NSA, which facilitated the transfer of millions of [[metadata]] records from the DGSE to the NSA.<ref name="lemonde1" /> In 2013, the existence of the Lustre treaty was revealed in documents leaked by the former NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name="lemonde1">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2013/10/30/surveillance-la-dgse-a-transmis-des-donnees-a-la-nsa-americaine_3505266_3210.html |title=Surveillance : la DGSE a transmis des données à la NSA américaine |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2013-10-30 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2013-11-01 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20131101055116/http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2013/10/30/surveillance-la-dgse-a-transmis-des-donnees-a-la-nsa-americaine_3505266_3210.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Signatories == ;[[France]] * {{flagicon|France}} [[Direction Générale de la Sécurité Extérieure]] (DGSE) of France<ref name="lemonde1"/><ref name="leparis"/><ref name="numera"/><ref name="zdnet"/> ;[[UKUSA Agreement|Five Eyes]] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Defence Signals Directorate]] (DSD) of Australia * {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Communications Security Establishment Canada|Communications Security Establishment]] of Canada (CSEC) * {{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[Government Communications Security Bureau]] (GCSB) of New Zealand * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ) of the United Kingdom * {{flagicon|United States}} [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) of the United States<ref name="lemonde1"/><ref name="leparis"/><ref name="numera"/><ref name="zdnet"/>
== Scale of surveillance ==
The French telecommunications corporation [[Orange S.A.]] shares customer call data with the French intelligence agency DGSE, and the intercepted data is handed over to GCHQ.<ref name="orangelemonde">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2014/03/20/dgse-orange-des-liaisons-incestueuses_4386264_3210.html |title=Espionnage : comment Orange et les services secrets coopèrent |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2014-03-20 |accessdate=2014-03-20 |archivedate=2014-03-20 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140320120950/http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2014/03/20/dgse-orange-des-liaisons-incestueuses_4386264_3210.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
From December 2012 to 8 January 2013, over 70 million [[metadata]] records were handed over to the NSA by French intelligence agencies.<ref name="lemonde1"/>
==See also == * [[UKUSA Agreement]]

{{copy edit|date=July 2018|for=Grammar and spelling|content=There needs to be more research on the topic, for a full range of ideas to the reader.}}
'''New Age Orientalism''' describes a modern, Western perception of [[Tibet]], and other Asian majority countries. The term was coined by, [[Tibetology|Tibetologist]] [[Donald S. Lopez Jr.|Donald Swell Lopez Jr.]], who specializes in Western discourse on [[Tibet]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Lopez Jr|first=Donald Sewell|date=1994|title=New age orientalism: the case of Tibet|url=|journal=Tricycle: The Buddhist Journal|volume=3|pages=36–43|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lsa.umich.edu/asian/people/faculty/dlopez.html|title=Donald S. Lopez Jr. {{!}} U-M LSA Asian Languages and Cultures|website=lsa.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-01}}</ref> A tibetologist is a person who studies [[tibetology]], the study of things related to [[Tibet]], including its [[History of Tibet|history]], [[Tibetan Buddhism|religion]], [[Standard Tibetan|language]], politics and the collection of Tibetan articles of historical, cultural and religious significance.<ref>{{Citation|title=Tibetology|date=2018-06-27|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tibetology&oldid=847768940|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-09-01}}</ref> [[Tibet]] is a [[historical region]] covering much of the [[Tibetan Plateau]] in Central Asia. It is the traditional homeland of the [[Tibetan people]] as well as some other [[Ethnic group|ethnic groups]] such as [[Monpa people|Monpa]], [[Qiang people|Qiang]], and [[Lhoba people|Lhoba peoples]] and is now also inhabited by considerable numbers of [[Han Chinese]] and [[Hui people]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Tibet|date=2018-08-27|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tibet&oldid=856854724|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-09-01}}</ref>
=='''Orientalism on Tibet'''==
[[Donald S. Lopez Jr.|Dr. Donald S. Lopez Jr.]] studied the depiction of Tibet in Western academic writing throughout history. He found that, before the New Age movement, the depiction of Tibet was often cynical and derogatory. The demeaning features that define Orientalism, characterized the portrayal of Tibet, before the emergence of New Age Orientalism.<ref name=":0" />
=== Self-aggrandizing of the Orient === In line with the logic of opposites, members of Western academia stressed their superiority (particularly regarding their academic abilities) and used this as a justification to patronize the Orient. With the modern period came Colonialism, when new knowledge of the Eastern world sparked western scholars to write about foreign histories, cultures, and traditions, despite having a sparse and incomplete understanding of them. The Western world, a majority of which was engaging in colonialism, considered The Eastern world to be incapable of representing itself due to its non-western mechanisms of knowledge. The colonial philosophy of manifest destiny led western scholars to believe that they had a more civilized and valuable way of expression, and so western academics took it upon themselves to document societies, such as Tibet, from their perspectives. Often described as 'backward' or 'incapable,' particularly in self-governance, such portrayals helped to fuel racist and white supremacist beliefs of Asian peoples across the west. Such western scholars considered both China and Tibet to be “Oriental Despotisms,” to which the politically organized and colonizing Western world was meant to civilize. {{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
=== Gaining and justifying authority === [[Manifest destiny]], along with larger ideologies of [[racism]] and [[white supremacy]], were used as a method of justifying imperialism and colonialism.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Mullen|first=Eve|date=2016|title=Orientalist commercializations: Tibetan Buddhism in American popular film|url=https://digitalcommons.unomaha.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1852&amp=&context=jrf&amp=&sei-redir=1&referer=https%253A%252F%252Fscholar.google.de%252Fscholar%253Fhl%253Dde%2526as_sdt%253D0%25252C5%2526q%253D%252522new%252Bage%252BOrientalism%252522%252Bmullen%2526oq%253Dmull#search=%22new%20age%20Orientalism%20mullen%22|journal=Journal of Religion & Film|volume=2.2|pages=|via=}}</ref> When control of Tibet was taken by western forces for periods of time, western understandings of self-superiority helped to fuel the sense of entitlement, which explained such [[Colonialism|colonial violence]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
However, western powers never fully succeeded in gaining imperial control of Tibet, despite [[British expedition to Tibet|Britain]] and [[Foreign relations of Tibet#Russia and The Great Game|Russia's]] considerable military efforts. According to a western-centric understanding, Tibet never [[Modernization theory|modernized,]] refusing to adopt European-style education systems or norms. Throughout the course of the 19th and 20th century, Tibet remained inaccessible to Western powers, and was therefore predominantly portrayed as isolated, closed, and uncivilized.<ref name=":0" />
=='''New Age Orientalism and Tibet'''==
Embedded in the [[New Age|New Age movement]], New Age Orientalism describes the positive Western perception of old Tibet (before the [[Chinese invasion of Tibet|Chinese invasion 1950]] and [[Tibetan diaspora|Tibetan diaspora 1959)]].<ref name=":0" /> This portrayal of Tibet in the modern Western Societies, has been criticized for romanticizing old Tibetan reality and neglecting negative aspects of its society, such as, violence or the clerical, feudal structure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SDuqayOx2Nw|title=Colin Goldner: Hinter dem Lächeln des Dalai Lama (Vortrag Univ. Wien 18.05.2012)|last=Goldner|first=Colin|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It is, therefore, seen as a construct of Western fantasy, rather than a depiction of reality.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=The myth of Shangri-La: Tibet, travel writing, and the western creatio of sacred landscape.|last=Bishop|first=Peter|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=1989|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name="ref6">{{Cite journal|last=Anand|first=Dibyesh|date=|title=Strategic hypocrisy: The British imperial scripting of Tibet's geopolitical identity|url=|journal=The Journal of Asian Studies|volume=68(1)|pages=227–252|via=}}</ref>
New Age Orientalism, subsequently, describes the [[Orientalism|orientalist]] perception of Tibet, in which Tibet is no longer depreciated but, rather, romanticized. It is based on the tradition of continued [[Romantic Orientalism]], “in which the ‘West’ perceives some lack within itself and fantasizes that the answer, through a process of projection, is to be found somewhere in the ‘East.'"<ref name=":0" /> In this manner, the four characteristics of Orientalism persist with slight variation. The logic of opposites, now relates to the old Tibet and China. Tibet is no longer perceived as an antiquated, "oriental despotism," but as a [[Shangri-La]] -- positive, holy, pristine, and pure, which is perceived as incorrupt, since it was never dominated by the West. The Chinese constitute the opposite, as the evil, subhuman force invading the land of peaceful, devoted inhabitants. The old Tibetan culture seems removed from time and history.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
This allows the West to aggrandize themselves as rescuers of Tibet and Tibetan Buddhism (see [[Free Tibet|'Free Tibet']] movement), whereas, [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]] are depicted as helpless and voiceless. Ultimately, the West again finds itself in a patronizing position, representing another culture.<ref name=":1" />
=== New Age Orientalism in popular culture ===
The romanticized picture of Tibet has, partly, been constructed and reflected by [[popular culture]]. Hollywood movies such as [[Seven Years in Tibet (1997 film)|Seven years in Tibet]], [[Kundun]], and [[Little Buddha]], were found to draw a [[Romanticism|romanticized]] image of Tibet, and hold up the Western rescue paradigm, in line with the play of opposites, between China and Tibet.<ref name=":1" /> Furthermore, publications surrounding the '[[Free Tibet]]' movement have been categorized as New Age Orientalism.<ref name=":3" /> The constructed fantasies of a Shangri-La Tibet, are found to reflect back on the Western struggles, within their own national identity,<ref name=":1" /> as well as, pitfalls of [[Globalization|globalization]].<ref name=":3" /> =='''Expansion of New Age Orientialism'''==
In academic literature, the concept of New Age Orientalism, originally relating to Tibet, has been expanded and applied to other cultures and religions, such as [[Hinduism]].<ref name="ref6" /> The discourse and perception on [[Ayurveda]], for instance, has been categorized as New Age Orientalism.<ref name="ref6" />
=='''Criticism of New Age Orientialism'''==
Dr. Donald Lopez's concept of New Age Orientalism, has been criticized for placing too much weight on the impact and power of Orientalism, and viewing Tibet as a closed totality, removed from history. Alternatives to Orientalism are not considered.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dreyfus|first=Georges|date=2005|title=Are We Prisoners of Shangrila? Orientalism, Nationalism, and the Study of Tibet|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Georges_Dreyfus2/publication/268361871_Are_We_Prisoners_of_Shangrila_Orientalism_Nationalism_and_the_Study_of_Tibet/links/5831ba9f08aef19cb819a8df.pdf|journal=Journal of the international association of Tibetan studies|volume=1.1|pages=1–21|via=Researchgate}}</ref> Moreover, the concept has been criticized for neglecting the Tibetan struggle under the Chinese occupation, in addition to not covering negative Oriental pictures of Old Tibet as feudal and antiquated to their fullest extent.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thurman|first=Robert A. F.|date=2001|title=Critical Reflections on Donald S. Lopez Jr.'s "Prisoners of Shangri-La: Tibetan Buddhism and the West"|jstor=1466076|journal=Journal of the American Academy of Religion|volume=69.1|pages=191–201}}</ref>
=='''References'''== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Orientalism]] [[Category:Tibet]] [[Category:New Age]] [[Category:Globalization]] __FORCETOC__

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=August 2017}} {{POV|date=June 2017}} }}
'''New constitutionalism''' is derived from the classical [[Neoliberalism|neo-liberalism]] framework and represents a set of political policies that promote a new global order.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Dierckx|first=Sacha|date=2013-12-01|title=After the Crisis and Beyond the New Constitutionalism? The Case of the Free Movement of Capital|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14747731.2013.814450|journal=Globalizations|volume=10|issue=6|pages=803–818|doi=10.1080/14747731.2013.814450|issn=1474-7731}}</ref> The goal of new constitutionalism is to separate the democratic and economic practices by shifting economic aims from the regional and national level to the global level through constitutional framework.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gill|first=Stephen|date=1998-02-01|title=New constitutionalism, democratisation and global political economy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14781159808412845|journal=Pacifica Review: Peace, Security & Global Change|volume=10|issue=1|pages=23–38|doi=10.1080/14781159808412845|issn=1323-9104}}</ref> The purpose of this shift is to create global supremacy and promote a free [[Capitalism|capitalist]] system.<ref name=":0" />
Central ideas of neoliberalism have been advanced to create policies and practices to achieve [[global governance]].<ref name=":1" /> New constitutionalism provides power to the private realm and limits power of state governance and public corporations.<ref name=":0" /> The transferring of power creates an informal self-regulatory setting allowing for the dismissal of public scrutiny and transparency.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=New Constitutionalism and World Order|last=Gill|first=Stephen|last2=Cutler|first2=Claire|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-107-05369-4|location=Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY|pages=7}}</ref> New constitutionalism has reshaped the structure of control to allow “locking in” mechanisms to occur to prevent intervention from the democratic realm and to enhance economic objectives.<ref name=":2" /> This protects markets from regional interference and allows global influence in order to promote [[imperialism]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=The New Constitutionalism: International and Private Rule in The New Global Order|last=McBride|first=Stephen|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4426-0365-3|editor-last=McBride|editor-first=Stephen|location=Toronto|pages=21|editor-last2=Teeple|editor-first2=Gary}}</ref>
The development of new constitutionalism is the result of [[globalization]] and the growing need for [[global hegemony]].<ref name=":2" /> Institutions have gained power in regards to trade, mobility, and flexibility through the framework of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization]], [[International Monetary Fund]], the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]], and the [[European Union]] are all actors contributing to the power of global supremacy.<ref name=":3" />
New constitutionalism as a political order emerged in the latter half of the 20th century and the term was coined by academic[[Stephen Gill (political scientist)|Stephen Gill]].<ref name=":1"/> The need for economic constitutional change was the result of crisis in political order correspondingly to the [[Russian Revolution]] and the [[Cold War]] as well as the progress of [[globalization]] through technological means.<ref name=":1" /> Since then the disciplinary has grown in acceptance due to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|global financial crisis]] of 2007 and the need for largescale stabilization in its aftermath.<ref name=":0" /> Theorists have subsequently developed the social and economic practices both in support and disagreement of the framework to provide a comparative outlook.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hilbink|first=Lisa|year=2008|title=Assessing the New Constitutionalism|url=https://www.jstor.org.subzero.lib.uoguelph.ca/stable/20434076?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents|journal=Comparative Politics|volume=40 [2]|pages=227–245|issn=0010-4159}}</ref>
== Origins == New constitutionalism formed in the 1980s as the result of a growing world order and the “worldwide market revolution.”<ref name=":2" /> The end of the [[Cold War]] represented an ideological shift and the need for transformation.<ref name=":2" /> This shift was reiterated by [[Margaret Thatcher|Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher]] declaring the depletion of [[socialism]] and the rise of [[conservatism]] and [[liberalism]].<ref name=":2" /> As society progressed it allowed for the evolution of capital mobility, [[Multinational corporation|transnational corporation]] and the expansion of the world market.<ref name=":2" /> The [[Great Depression]] and the aftermath of [[World War II]] reflected the need for reform.<ref name=":1" /> Reform would redirect economic and political practices, ensuring benefits for all through the creation of global institutions.<ref name=":5">Falk, R. (2014). New Constitutionalism and geopolitics: notes on legality and legitimacy and prospects for a just new constitutionalism. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 295-312. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}.</ref>
Neo-liberal supremacy through the dominance of the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]] allowed for geopolitical reconfiguration increasing the need for new political order.<ref name=":2" /> Additionally the lack of consistency among nation-state principles and the constant interruption from democratic power influenced the need to provide sustainable long term economic goals by limiting [[Executive (government)|executive]] and [[Legislature|legislative]] branches of government using [[Constitution|constitutional framework]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4">Cutler, A. Claire. (2016) "Transformations in Statehood, the Investor-State Regime, and the New Constitutionalism." ''Indiana Journal of Global Legal Studies'' 23, no. 1: 95-125.</ref> New constitutionalism has become prominent in the aftermath of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2007 global financial crisis]] as a result of the need to bypass formal trade rules and democratic controls.<ref name=":0" /><ref>Schneiderman, D. (2014). How to govern differently: neo-liberal, new constitutionalism and international investment law. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 159-175. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}. </ref>
== Framework == There are four main [[Policy|policies]] to define new constitutionalism.<ref name=":2" /> The first represents the development of a constitutional structure for the global market that dictates the public, private and international powers.<ref name=":2" /> These international economic agreements or “[[constitution]]s” resemble political constitutions and thus ensure [[sovereignty]].<ref name=":3" /> The economic power is being shifted from the national to the international as well as from the public to the private to provide growth and sustainability.<ref name=":3" />
Second is the separation of economic policies from domestic influence.<ref name=":2" /> This allows for capitalist markets to grow as well as extending the commodity form and the market forces.<ref name=":2" />''' ''' This separation insulates economic policies from governing regulatory powers as well as the public demand for transparency.<ref name=":3" /> [[Economic Liberation Movement|Economic liberation]] is usually accompanied by political backlash, by disconnecting these two dynamisms suppresses democratic involvement.<ref name=":1" /> [[World Bank Group|The World Bank]] advocates for the restriction of democratic participation and limitations imposed in the economic realm by creating a hierarchical system of representation.<ref name=":1" />
Thirdly is creating “locking in” mechanisms which incorporate; laws, rules, regulations, procedures and institutions.<ref name=":2" /> This mechanism puts limitations on legislative and policy autonomy.<ref name=":1" /> Agreements are formulated to “lock in” [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] content through legal guarantees and sanctions.<ref name=":1" /> These agreements are difficult, even impossible to change which makes economic policies autonomous.<ref name=":3" />
Lastly this process diminished the need for formal accountability.<ref name=":2" /> New constitutionalism has created a flexible system giving privileges to [[Multinational corporation|international corporations]] and private entities creating a “double” legal standard.<ref name=":2" /> This concept diminished the “watchdog” and gives the flexibility for self-regulation.<ref name=":2" /> This instrument is based on the international gold standard of the [[19th century|nineteenth century]] which gave rights to investor to avoid certain jurisdictions.<ref name=":1" /> Permitting deregulation of financial services and trade investment avoids popular pressures and limits the need for transparency.<ref name=":4" /> Minimizing liability and ensuring private authority the economic sector becomes more efficient, functional and practical.<ref name=":6">Cutler, C. (2011). The Privatization of Authority in the Global Political Economy''.'' Edited by McBride, S., & Teeple, G. ''In'' ''Relations of global power: Neoliberal order and disorder''. (p.41-59). Toronto: University of Toronto Press. {{ISBN|978-1-4426-0365-3}}</ref>
== Institutions == At the global and regional level institutions are implementing the new constitutionalism framework to advance [[global governance]] by upholding the rights of private corporations and promoting a free [[Capitalism|capitalist]] society.<ref name=":3" /> These institutions policies will ensure [[economic growth]] at the global level.<ref name=":7">Sinclair, S. (2014). Trade agreements, the new constitutionalism and public services. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 179-195. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}</ref>
=== Global === The [[World Trade Organization]] [[World Trade Organization|(WTO)]] is a prominent figure in governing the [[World economy|global economy]].<ref name=":3" /> Formally it was the responsibility of [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade|General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade]] built on [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] principles but lacked the greater power adapted through new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization]] represents a governing global entity which has adapted to the principles of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] main purpose is to limit national interference in the global market and challenge any nation-state regulations that could be detrimental to the economy.<ref name=":3" /> Any economic alternatives that are proposed by nations can be discredited by the [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] as well as restricting governments ability to implement policy in international jurisdiction.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] represents the freedom of markets and allowing investors to capitalize in a [[world economy]], by doing so provides protection to the private sector.<ref name=":3" /> Stephen McBride describes the [[World Trade Organization]] as having “quasi-judicial and quasi-constitutional aura.”<ref name=":3" /> The judicial and constitutional supremacy highlights the difficulty in challenging the organizations because of lock in mechanisms.<ref name=":3" />
=== Regional === The [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] ([[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]]) is a considered a regional governing entity that encompasses the principles of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> [[Ronald Reagan|President Ronald Regan]] referred to the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] as a “new economic constitution.”<ref name=":3" /> Constitution because the agreement provided restrictions on government intrusion, rights to certain actors and enforcement mechanisms.<ref name=":3" /> The binding agreement afforded rights to both foreign and domestic investor to protect the interests of private capital and corporations.<ref name=":7" /> By limiting government powers the agreement locked in private interests and reduced governments ability to expand or restore [[public service]]s in [[free trade]].<ref name=":7" />
== Criticisms == Focus at the global level has resulted in hostility between the public and private realms within [[nation state]]s.<ref name=":6" /> This hostility creates a political struggle between the private sector who safeguard the rights of capital and the public who want to control [[capitalism]] politically, democracy and socially.<ref name=":0" /> The control is being denationalized and delocalized causing negative repercussions at state level.<ref name=":4" /> New constitutionalism lacks political will and can have detrimental effects to global dignity and future generations.<ref name=":5" /> Dividing economic policies from domestic creates disturbances within the civil society.<ref name=":4" /> [[Human rights]], [[Environmental issue|environmental concerns]] and [[public service]]s are being devalued because of the lack of economic concern.<ref name=":4" />
New constitutionalism favours the [[Elitism|elitists]] providing preferential treatment and widening the [[Economic inequality|social gap]].<ref name=":4" /> [[International financial institutions]], [[investor]]s and bond-raters are holding higher positions of authority than governments or nation-states furthering global supremacy.<ref name=":1" /> There is an urgent need for surveillance, policy making power, regulations and transparency economic outcomes are not solely focused on monetary gain but [[Humanitarianism|humanitarian]] concerns as well.<ref name=":5" /> The absence of accountability and democratic authority has led many countries to depart from the constitutional framework and reclaim their [[sovereignty]] as independent nations.<ref name=":4" /> [[Australia]] has begun to constrain the advancements of new constitutionalism while many [[South America]] states have begun to exit the global regime completely.<ref name=":4" /> [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] have begun to form provisions to improve the democratic power within the global order and no longer allow for their governments to be immobilized.<ref name=":4" />

{{multiple issues| {{Globalize|date=January 2012}} {{Update|date=September 2010}} }} [[File:Energy per capita.png|thumb|300px|[[World energy resources and consumption|Energy consumption]] per capita per country in 2001]] [[File:CO2 per capita per country.png|thumb|300px|[[List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions per capita|CO2 emission per capita]] per year per country pre-2006]] '''Overconsumption''' is a situation where [[resource consumption|resource use]] has outpaced the [[sustainable]] [[carrying capacity|capacity]] of the [[ecosystem]]. A prolonged pattern of overconsumption leads to [[environmental degradation]] and the eventual [[resource depletion|loss of resource]] bases. Generally, the discussion of overconsumption parallels that of [[human overpopulation]];{{cite journal| last1=Ceballos|first1=Gerardo|last2=Ehrlich|first2=Paul R |last3=Dirzo|first3=Rodolfo|date=23 May 2017|title=Biological annihilation via the ongoing sixth mass extinction signaled by vertebrate population losses and declines|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/07/05/1704949114.full|journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|PNAS]]|volume=114|issue=30|pages=E6089–E6096|doi=10.1073/pnas.1704949114|quote=Much less frequently mentioned are, however, the ultimate drivers of those immediate causes of biotic destruction, namely, human overpopulation and continued population growth, and overconsumption, especially by the rich. These drivers, all of which trace to the fiction that perpetual growth can occur on a finite planet, are themselves increasing rapidly.|pmc=5544311|pmid=28696295}} that is the more people, the more [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]] of [[raw material]]s takes place to sustain their lives. But, humanity's overall impact on the planet is affected by many factors besides the raw number of people. Their lifestyle (including overall affluence and resource utilization) and the pollution they generate (including [[carbon footprint]]) are equally important. Currently, the inhabitants of the [[developed nation]]s of the world consume resources at a rate almost 32 times greater than those of the developing world, who make up the majority of the human population (7.4 billion people).Diamond, Jared: (2008-01-02). [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/02/opinion/02diamond.html "What's Your Consumption Factor?"] ''[[The New York Times]]'' However, the developing world is a growing market of consumption. These nations are quickly gaining more purchasing power and it is expected that the Global South, which includes cities in Asia, Latin America and Africa, will account for 56% of consumption growth by 2030.Richard Dobbs, James Manyika, Jonathan Woetzel, Jaana Remes, Jesko Perrey, Greg Kelly, Kanaka Pattabiraman, and Hemant Sharma. (2016, March). Urban world: The global consumers to watch. Retrieved November 05, 2017, from https://www.mckinsey.com/global-themes/urbanization/urban-world-the-global-consumers-to-watch This means that consumption rates will plateau for the developed nations and shift more into these developing countries. The theory of overpopulation reflects issues of [[Carrying capacity#Humans|carrying capacity]] without taking into account per capita consumption, by which developing nations are evaluated to consume more than their land can support. It is expected that world population growth will increase by 41% from 2000 to 2050, reaching a height of 8.9 billion people. On top of the rapid growth expectancy, it will be highly concentrated in the developing nations. This poses issues with inequality of consumption as well. The nations that will come into consumer dominance must abstain from abusing certain forms of consumption, especially energy consumption of CO2.RICHARD FLORIDA. (2016, April 14). Big Cities Are the Future of Global Consumption. Retrieved November 5, 2017, from https://www.citylab.com/life/2016/04/big-cities-are-the-future-of-global-consumption/478128/ [[Green party|Green parties]] and the [[ecology movement]] often argue that consumption per person, or [[ecological footprint]], is typically lower in poor than in rich nations. ==Causes== In understanding the effects of over-consumption, it is pertinent to understand what causes the phenomenon. There is a spectrum of goods and services that the world population constantly consume. These range from food and beverage, clothing and footwear, housing, energy, technology, transportation, education, health and personal care, financial services and other utilities.The World Bank Group - www.worldbank.org. (n.d.). The developing world’s 4.5 billion low-income people already a $5 trillion market. Retrieved November 05, 2017, from http://datatopics.worldbank.org/consumption/market Each of these require a different resource and once that resource is exploited to a certain point, that qualifies as over consumption. Since the developing nations are rising quickly into the consumer class, it is important to note the trends happening in these nations. According to the World Bank, the highest shares of consumption lie in food and beverage and clothing and footwear. This applies regardless of sector of income. The World Bank Group - www.worldbank.org. (n.d.). The developing world’s 4.5 billion low-income people already a $5 trillion market. Retrieved November 05, 2017, from http://datatopics.worldbank.org/consumption/market Two main factors of why we buy so much and so often is due to planned and perceived obsolescence.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9GorqroigqM This factor of production was introduced first in the United States and it revolves around the design of products and with these methods, the products are intentionally designed to get rid of after a short amount of time. As of 2012, only 1% of goods purchased were still in use after 6 months. This is due to planned and perceived obsolescence. When it is planned, designers create products that will not be able to work after a certain amount of time but they work for enough time to ensure the customers will come back to buy again. Perceived obsolescence comes in a lot with fashion and trends and fueled by advertising and media consumption. Through this technique, consumers are convinced that certain products do not have value anymore because it is out of style, and in order to have value, consumers must buy more up to date styles. Here is where fast fashion was born. As of 2015, the top five consumer markets in the world included the United States, Japan, Germany, China and France. The 25 Largest Consumer's Markets ... And The Outlook For 2015. (n.d.). Retrieved November 05, 2017, from https://www.internationalbusinessguide.org/25-largest-consumers-markets-outlook-2015/ ==Effects== {{See also|I PAT}} A fundamental effect of overconsumption is a reduction in the planet's [[carrying capacity]]. Excessive unsustainable consumption will exceed the long term carrying capacity of its environment ([[Overshoot (ecology)|ecological overshoot]]) and subsequent resource depletion, [[environmental degradation]] and reduced [[ecosystem health]]. Looking at the two largest sectors of over consumption, the fashion and food industries, we can see most of the harmful effects on the Earth starting here. The fashion industry has created a new venue, fast fashion, which in 2013 produced 15.1 million tons of textile waste and of that, 12.8 million tons were thrown out. The United States, being the largest consumer market, deals with excess clothing by exporting it to poorer, developing nations but this solution is not sustainable because the demand will go down as cheap clothing becomes more readily available. Another way of disposal is to throw out into landfills or burn up in incinerators which is the least sustainable disposal solution. Tan, Z. Y. (2016, April 10). What Happens When Fashion Becomes Fast, Disposable And Cheap? Retrieved November 05, 2017, from https://www.npr.org/2016/04/08/473513620/what-happens-when-fashion-becomes-fast-disposable-and-cheap The food industry is the other largest sector of consumption and studies show that people waste a fifth of food products just through disposal or overconsumption. The UN Food and Agriculture Organization collected data and found that by the time food reaches the consumer, 9% (160 million tons) goes uneaten and 10% is lost to overconsumption - meaning consumers ate more than the calorie intake requirement. Other aspects of losses surrounding dry matter came at each stage in the food system, the highest amount being from livestock production at 43.9%, transportation accounted for 18% and consumer waste accounting for 12.2% loss. When the consumer takes in too much, this not only explains losses in the beginning of the stage at production (and over production) but also lends itself to overconsumption of energy and protein, having harmful effects on the body. Beer, E. (2017, February 27). Consumer waste and livestock biggest inefficiencies in food production: Study. Retrieved November 05, 2017, from https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2017/02/27/Consumer-waste-and-livestock-biggest-inefficiencies-in-food-production-Study The scale of modern life's overconsumption has enabled an [[overclass]] to exist, displaying [[affluenza]] and [[obesity]] {{cite web|last1=Nierenberg|first1=Danielle|title=State of the World 2006: a Worldwatch Institute report on progress toward a sustainable society|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/state-of-the-world-2006-a-worldwatch-institute-report-on-progress-toward-a-sustainable-society/oclc/62865904|website=Worldcat|publisher=New York; London: W.W. Norton|accessdate=4 May 2018}}. However once again both of these claims are controversial with the latter being correlated to other factors more so than over-consumption. Within the topic of overconsumption there are many other ideas that should be considered in order to find the true cause of it. Some important events that coincide are poverty, population and the development of an area.{{cite web|title=Overpopulation and overconsumption|url=https://www.bmj.com/content/306/6888/1285|website=BMJ|publisher=BMJ|accessdate=6 May 2018}} Overconsumption can also lead to a decline in the economy and financial instability. {{cite web|last1=Vidal|first1=John|title=World needs to stabilise population and cut consumption, says Royal Society|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/apr/26/earth-population-consumption-disasters|website=The Guardian|accessdate=6 May 2018}} In the long term, these effects can lead to increased conflict over dwindling resources [http://www.globalissues.org/EnvIssues/Population/Result.asp Effects of Over-Consumption and Increasing Populations]. 26 September 2001. Retrieved on 19 June 2007 and in the worst case a [[Malthusian catastrophe]]. [[Lester Brown]] of the [[Earth Policy Institute]], has said: "It would take 1.5 Earths to sustain our present level of consumption. Environmentally, the world is in an overshoot mode."{{cite book |last=Brown |first=Lester R. |title=World on the Edge: How to Prevent Environmental and Economic Collapse |publisher=Norton |series=Earth Policy Institute |year=2011 |page=7 |isbn =113654075X}} As of 2012, the United States alone was using 30% of the world’s resources and if everyone were to consume at that rate, we would need 3-5 planets to sustain this type of living. Resources are quickly becoming depleted, with about ⅓ already gone. With new consumer markets rising in the developing countries which account for a much higher percent of the world’s population, this number can only rise. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9GorqroigqM ===Economic growth=== The [[Worldwatch Institute]] said China and India, with their booming economies, along with the United States, are the three planetary forces that are shaping the global [[biosphere]].{{Cite book|last=Renner|first=Michael|title=State of the world 2005: A Worldwatch Institute Report on progress toward a sustainable society.|url=http://www.worldwatch.org/node/3866|accessdate=2009-09-14|date=January 2006|publisher=[[W.W. Norton]]|location=New York|isbn=0-393-32666-7|oclc=57470324|chapter=Chapter 1: China, India, and the New World Order|chapterurl=http://www.worldwatch.org/node/3992}} The [[State of the World (book series)|State of the World]] 2005 report said the two countries' high [[economic growth]] exposed the reality of severe pollution. The report states that
The world's ecological capacity is simply insufficient to satisfy the ambitions of China, India, Japan, Europe and the United States as well as the aspirations of the rest of the world in a sustainable way.
==Footprint== {{main article|Ecological footprint}} {{quote box|align=right|width=25em|quote=If everyone consumed resources at the US level, you will need another four or five Earths.|source=—[[Paul R. Ehrlich]], biologist[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/feb/25/half-all-species-extinct-end-century-vatican-conference Biologists say half of all species could be extinct by end of century]. ''[[The Guardian]].'' February 25, 2017.}} The idea of overconsumption is also strongly tied to the idea of an ecological footprint. The term “ecological footprint” refers to the “resource accounting framework for measuring human demand on the biosphere.” Currently, China is roughly 11 times lower in per capita footprint, yet has a population that is more than four times the size of the USA. It is estimated that if China developed to the level of the United States that world consumption rates would roughly double. According to Scientific American, one person from China uses 53 times fewer resources than the average American.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/american-consumption-habits/|title=American Consumption|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} A 2018 study published in ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' postulates that meat consumption is set to increase as the result of [[human population growth]] and rising affluence, which will increase greenhouse gas emissions and further reduce [[biodiversity]].{{cite news |last= Devlin|first=Hannah |date=July 19, 2018 |title=Rising global meat consumption 'will devastate environment'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jul/19/rising-global-meat-consumption-will-devastate-environment|work=The Guardian |location= |access-date=July 26, 2018 }} ==Counteractions== The most obvious solution to the issue of overconsumption is to simply slow the rate at which materials are becoming [[Resource depletion|depleted]]. Less consumption naturally has negative effects on economies - so instead, countries must look to curb consumption rates while allowing for new industries, such as [[renewable energy]] and [[recycling]] technologies, to flourish and deflect some of the economic burden. A fundamental shift in the global economy may be necessary in order to account for the current change that is taking place or that will need to take place. Movements and lifestyle choices related to stopping overconsumption include: [[anti-consumerism]], [[freeganism]], [[green economics]], [[ecological economics]], [[degrowth]], [[frugality]], [[Downshifting (lifestyle)|downshifting]], [[simple living]], [[The Minimalists|minimalism]], and thrifting. Recent grassroots movements have been coming up with creative ways to decrease the amount of goods we consume. [[The Freecycle Network]] is a network of people in one's community that are willing to trade goods for other goods or services. It is a new take on thrifting while still being beneficial to both parties.{{Cite web|url=https://www.freecycle.org/|title=The Freecycle Network|website=www.freecycle.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-18}}
Other researchers and movements such as [[the Zeitgeist Movement]] suggest a new socioeconomic model which, through a structural increase of [[efficiency]], collaboration and locality in production as well as effective [[sharing economy|sharing]], increased [[modularity]], sustainability and optimal design of products, are expected to reduce resource-consumption.[http://www.thezeitgeistmovement.com/faq The Zeitgeist Movement - Frequently Asked Questions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815095626/http://thezeitgeistmovement.com/faq |date=2012-08-15 }} Retrieved on 6 May 2014 Added information about overconsumption and excess garbage and its effect on urban communities and the environment. Solutions offered include consumers using market forces to influence businesses towards more sustainable manufacturing and products. Derraik, J. (2002). The pollution of the marine environment by plastic debris: a review. Marine Pollution Bulletin, 22(9), pp. 842-852. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0025-326X(02)00220-5 ==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable Development|Environment}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Artificial demand]] *[[Collaborative consumption]] *[[Conspicuous consumption]] *[[Consumption (economics)]] *[[Degrowth]] *[[Environmental studies]] *[[Externality]] *[[Mottainai]] *[[Overexploitation]] *[[Overshoot (population)]] *[[Peak copper]] *[[Peak oil]] *[[Preorder economy]] *[[Santosha]] (renunciation of the need to acquire) *[[Steady-state economy]] *''[[Surplus: Terrorized into Being Consumers]]'' (film) {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite journal|last1=Ivanova |first1=Diana |last2= Stadler|first2= Konstantin|last3= Steen-Olsen|first3= Kjartan |last4= Wood |first4= Richard|last5= Vita|first5= Gibran |last6= Tukker|first6= Arnold|last7= Hertwich|first7=Edgar G. |date = 18 December 2015 | title = Environmental Impact Assessment of Household Consumption |journal=[[Journal of Industrial Ecology]] |volume= 20 |issue=3| pages =526–536 | url = |doi=10.1111/jiec.12371|format=|pmid=| bibcode=}} ==External links== * [http://www.earthhealing.info/fifty.htm Fifty Possible Ways to Challenge Over-Commercialism] by Albert J. Fritsch, SJ, PhD * [http://www.spiked-online.com/newsite/article/670 Why people hate fat Americans] by [[Daniel Ben-Ami]] * [http://www.optimumpopulation.org Optimum Population Trust] * [https://www.un.org/esa/sustdev/documents/agenda21/english/agenda21chapter4.htm UN Division for Sustainable Development, Agenda 21, Chapter 4 – "Changing Consumption Patterns"] * [http://www.footprintnetwork.org/en/index.php/GFN/page/footprint_for_nations/ Footprint For Nations] * ''[http://www.storyofstuff.org/movies-all/story-of-stuff/ The Story of Stuff]'' (video) * [http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/ene_oil_con-energy-oil-consumption Energy statistics-Oil Consumption by Country] * [http://www.google.com/publicdata?ds=wb-wdi&met=eg_use_pcap_kg_oe&tdim=true&dl=en&hl=en&q=world+energy+use+graph World Energy Use Graph] * [http://www.data360.org/dsg.aspx?Data_Set_Group_Id=591 Global GDP by Country] * [http://habitat.igc.org/agenda21/ch-06.html] {{Human impact on the environment}} {{Population}} {{Population country lists}} {{Sustainability}} {{Environmental social science}} {{Fast culture}} {{biological organisation}} {{Globalization|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Consumerism]] [[Category:Waste minimisation]] [[Category:Peak oil]] [[Category:Population ecology]] [[Category:World population]] [[Category:Global issues]] [[Category:Environmental controversies]] [[Category:Environmental social science concepts]] [[Category:Human activities with impact on the environment]]

'''The Partnership for Maternal, Newborn & Child Health''' (PMNCH) is a multi-constituency partnership hosted by the [[World Health Organization]] and chaired by [[Graça Machel]]. PMNCH seeks to achieve universal access to comprehensive, high-quality reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health care. PMNCH works with more than 650 members in the reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health (RMNCH) communities across seven constituencies:
# Academic research and teaching institutions # Donors and foundations # Health-care professionals # Multilateral agencies # Non-governmental organizations # Partner countries # The private sector
PMNCH describes itself as "a platform for knowledge, advocacy and accountability to improve women and children’s health". The Partnership is governed by a Board chaired by [[Graça Machel]].
==Main Activities==
The Partnership plays a central role in facilitating joint action on many fronts, mainly progress towards the [[United Nations]] [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs) 4 and 5, to reduce child mortality and improve maternal health, as tracked by the Countdown to 2015 initiative, and through support for the [[Global Strategy for Women's and Children's Health|Global Strategy for Women’s and Children’s Health]] (Global Strategy) and Every Woman Every Child. PMNCH enables members to share strategies, align objectives and resources, and collectively agree on policy interventions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reaching Every Woman and Every Child through Partnership|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/knowledge/publications/20130620_pmnchbrochurelowres.pdf?ua=1|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
PMNCH’s work and support to partners is focused on three key Strategic Objectives: # Promotion of knowledge and innovation for action in order to enhance policy, service delivery and financing mechanisms. # Advocacy to mobilize and consolidate resources and greater engagement towards RMNCH. # Promotion of accountability for resources and results in order to strengthen monitoring of RMNCH’s efforts.
The Partnership issues annual reports on progress of commitments from more than 250 stakeholders and estimates that the Global Strategy has leveraged over US$18 billion in new and additional money for women’s and children’s health.<ref>{{cite web|title=The PMNCH 2013 Report|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/knowledge/publications/2013_pmnch_report/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
==History==
PMNCH was launched in September 2005 when the world’s three leading maternal, newborn and child health alliances joined forces under the new name of The Partnership for Maternal, Newborn & Child Health. 80 original members joined together from the three organizations, which included: the Partnership for Safe Motherhood and Newborn Health, hosted by the World Health Organization in Geneva; the Healthy Newborn Partnership, based at [[Save the Children]] USA; and the Child Survival Partnership, hosted by [[Unicef|UNICEF]] in New York. All three partnerships focused on accelerating action by countries—both donor and developing countries—to achieve Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 4 ([[Child mortality|reduce child mortality]]) and 5 ([[Maternal health|improve maternal health]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=PMNCH History|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/about/history/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
==Board Members<ref>{{cite web|title=Board, PMNCH|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/about/governance/board/en/|website=World Health Organization}}</ref>==
As of July 2014, the following bodies are represented on the PMNCH Board. The Board is chaired by Mrs Graça Machel and co-chaired by Mr CK Mishra, [[Government of India]] and Dr Flavia Bustreo, the [[World Health Organization]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Chairs, PMNCH|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/about/governance/board/chairs/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
===Partner countries=== * Government of Indonesia * Government of Tanzania * Government of Nigeria * Government of India
===Multilateral organizations=== * [[United Nations Population Fund]] (UNFPA) (Permanent seat) * [[Unicef|United Nations Children’s Fund]] (UNICEF) (permanent seat) * [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) (Permanent seat) * The [[World bank|World Bank]] (Permanent seat)
===Donors and foundations=== * The [[Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation]] (NORAD) * [[USAID|U.S. Agency for International Development]] (USAID) * [[Department for International Development|Department of International Development]], (DFID) (UK) * [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]] * [[Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development|Government of Canada]]
===Non-governmental organizations=== * [[Save the Children]] * [[White Ribbon Alliance for Safe Motherhood|White Ribbon Alliance]] * [[International Planned Parenthood Federation]] (IPPF) * [[World Vision International]]
===Health care professionals=== * [[International Confederation of Midwives]] * [[International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics]] (FIGO) * [[International Paediatric Association]]
===Private sector=== * [[Johnson & Johnson]] * [[GSM Association]] * [[Novartis Foundation]] * [[Pfizer]]
===Academic, research and teaching institutions=== * Government of Zambia and University Teaching Hospital * [[UCL Institute for Global Health|Institute for Global Health]], [[University College London]] * Institute for Clinical Effectiveness and Health Policy (IECS) <ref>{{cite web|title=Board Members, PMNCH|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/about/governance/board/members/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 September 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Independent Accountability Panel]]
==External links== * [http://www.who.int/pmnch/en/ The Partnership for Maternal, Newborn & Child Health website]

[[File:The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg|thumb|right|The Earth Seen from Apollo 17]] '''Planetary consciousness''' is the idea that human beings are members of a planetary society of [[Earth]] as much as they are members of their nations, provinces, districts, islands, cities or villages.
== History == In his 1906 book ''American Character'', author [[Brander Matthews]] mentions the idea of a "league of nations" and a "planetary consciousness", believing it would be created by American politicians in the coming centuries.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=UA2WY1GvV-oC&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22League+of+Nations%22+%22planetary+consciousness%22+-wikipedia#v=onepage&q=%22League%20of%20Nations%22%20%22planetary%20consciousness%22%20-wikipedia&f=false | author=Matthews, Brander | authorlink=Brander Matthews | title=American Character | page=187 | publisher=Thomas Y. Crowell & Co |date=September 1906}}</ref> Key planetary consciousness events of the 20th century include the creation of the [[League of Nations]], the signing of [[Kellogg-Briand Pact]], the creation of the [[United Nations]], and the creation of the [[Bretton Woods system]]. [[Democratic globalization]] advocate [[Abhay Kumar]] points to the [[ICANN|International Corporation of Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN) board of directors election in 2000, which were conducted globally, as the first example of global democracy.<ref name=abhay>{{cite news | title=Birth of Global Democracy | author=K, Abhay | authorlink=Abhay Kumar | work=[[Times of India]] | date=21 January 2011 | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-01-21/edit-page/28367706_1_printing-press-number-of-mobile-phones-gutenberg | accessdate=13 August 2012}}</ref> In September 2001, [[Ervin László]] and the [[Dalai Lama]] wrote an essay titled "Manifesto on Planetary Consciousness", which was adopted at a meeting at the [[Hungarian Academy of Sciences]] in Budapest.<ref name=manifesto>{{cite web | author1=László, Ervin | authorlink1=Ervin László | author2=[[Dalai Lama]] | title=Manifesto on Planetary Consciousness | publisher=WorldShift International | date=15 September 2001 | url=http://www.worldshiftinternational.org/manifesto-planetary-consciousness/ | accessdate=13 August 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120828003626/http://www.worldshiftinternational.org/manifesto-planetary-consciousness/ | archivedate=28 August 2012 | df= }}</ref> Its introduction begins:
{{cquote|text=In the closing years of the twentieth century, we have reached a crucial juncture in our history. We are on the threshold of a new stage of social, spiritual, and cultural evolution, a stage that is as different from the stage of the earlier decades of this century as the grasslands were from the caves, and settled villages from life in nomadic tribes. We are evolving out of the nationally based industrial societies that were created at the dawn of the first industrial revolution, and heading toward an interconnected, information-based social, economic, and cultural system that straddles the globe.<ref name=manifesto/>}}
[[Andreas Bummel]], CEO of the Committee for a Democratic UN, says, "The first step into the direction of a world parliament would be the establishment of a Parliamentary Assembly at the United Nations".<ref name=bummel/>
==Concept== Advocacy for the idea of planetary consciousness is based on the technological advancements made by the mankind in the fields of transport and telecommunications during the 20th century and in the first decade of the 21st century.<ref name=abhay/> Kumar claims that these technological advancements have turned the whole planet into an interdependent economic, political and communication community.<ref name=abhay/> He specifically cites the invention of the Internet and the mobile phones as key technological achievements of the 20th century which brought humans into more continuous interconnected communication.<ref name=abhay/> He believes that these inventions will lead to a second [[Renaissance]] and global democracy, just as the [[Gutenberg press]] in 1439 led to the first Renaissance, the [[Age of Enlightenment]], and [[Nation state]]s.<ref name=abhay/> Bummel describes planetary consciousness as integral, insofar as it does not conflict with other levels of [[Identity (social science)|social identity]], but instead is a holistic perspective on humanity and the planet as a whole.<ref name=bummel>{{cite journal | title=Social Evolution, Global Governance and a World Parliament | author=Bummel, Andreas | journal=[[Cadmus (journal)|Cadmus]] | date=11 April 2012 |url=http://www.cadmusjournal.org/article/issue-4/social-evolution-global-governance-and-world-parliament#13 | accessdate=13 August 2012}}</ref> Steven Kull writes that while nation states are reluctant to work cooperatively, individuals seem more willing.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Kull, Steven | title=Listening to the Voice of Humanity | journal= Kosmos Journal | issue=Spring/Summer | year= 2010 | pages=26–29}}</ref>
Author [[Shashi Tharoor]] feels that an [[Earth Anthem]] sung by people across the world can inspire planetary consciousness and [[global citizenship]] among people.<ref>[http://newindianexpress.com/nation/Indian-diplomat-pens-anthem-for-earth/2013/06/05/article1620381.ece Indian diplomat pens anthem for earth] The New Indian Express 5 June 2013</ref>
==See also== * [[Earth Anthem]] * [[Global citizenship]]
